block.p: Best Bet

The holiday weekend gets its customary musical fireworks send-off Friday at Bar Beach in Port Washington with a Salute to Veterans and the Big Band All-Stars at 6 p.m. and Alive and Kickin' at 7:45 p.m. (516) 327-3110 and at Hempstead Harbor Beach Park (516) 571-7930.

Tradition also plays a major part in most of the other celebrations. For example, Old Bethpage Village Restoration on Round Swamp Road has its 11th Annual Spring Festival, with 19th-century music and dance, military drills, crafts demonstrations, period ''base ball,'' a crafts show and sale and the 23rd Annual Historical Exhibition of Long Island Horticulture. 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday through Monday (516) 572-8401.

In Huntington, the 28th Annual Renaissance Faire, complete with battling knights, medieval theater, music and crafts, pony rides and food, takes up residence from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Saturday and 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. next Sunday at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship on Brown's Road. (631) 427-9547.

The Southold Historical Society stages its Founders Weekend Celebration, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday and next Sunday, with a Civil War re-enactment and crafts demonstrations on the museum grounds on Main Road. (631) 765-5500.

Among other community events are a festival in Levittown from Thursday through Monday on Hempstead Turnpike with fireworks on Saturday, (516) 520-8000, and in East Rockaway, a 100th anniversary celebration Saturday through May 31 with a parade and Cultural Arts Fair at Memorial Park Park from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and a concert by the Banjo Rascals at 7 p.m., both on Saturday, (516) 593-3905.
Gould Tribute

Since he lived in Great Neck, it figures that the late Morton Gould would warrant special attention from his neighbors. So the Great Neck Choral Society today devotes its spring concert to ''Remembering Morton Gould.'' Under the direction of Virginia Davidson, the program, at 3 p.m. at the Congregational Church of Manhasset on Northern Boulevard, features two Gould a cappella double choruses, ''Tolling'' and ''Solfegging,'' along with works by Lili Boulanger, Otto Lueniing, Marc-Antoine Charpentier, Frank Martin and Theron Kirk. (516) 829-8345.

Two other choral groups contribute to today's musical lineup: the Long Island Choral Society, under the baton of Meredith Elaine Baker, and joined by Marissa Ramirez, pianist, and Seth Nadler, tenor -- both winners of the group's 19th Annual Young Artist Competition. The program includes selections from ''Ragtime,'' spirituals and other works. 4 p.m. at Cathedral House, on Cathedral Avenue in Garden City. (516) 679-2136. And the Silver Chords offer ''Rainbows of Spring,'' 1 p.m., Islip High School on Union Boulevard. (631) 423-7807.
The Choral Pops of Long Island has Friday all to itself when it performs ''Bach to Broadway'' at 7:30 p.m. at the Northport Library on Laurel Avenue. (631) 261-6930.
All That Jazz

With four concerts in the offing, today is also a good day for jazz buffs. At 3 p.m. the Dave Carter Quintet, with Jacque Washington, vocalist, appears in the ''Jazz Revelations'' series at St. John's Episcopal Church on South Franklin Street in Hempstead. (516) 538-4750. Also at 3 p.m., in free concerts, Kenny Barron, pianist, performs at the Landmark on Main Street in Port Washington, (516) 883-4400, while Linda Ciofalo, jazz vocalist, performs at the Massapequa Library on Harbor Lane in Massapequa Park, (516) 795-7528. Joined by her band, Ms. Ciofalo then moves north to Centerport to perform in a Vanderbilt Planetarium ''Music Under the Dome'' outing at 6:30 p.m. (631) 854-5550.
Goodbye, Vic

In his 53rd year as a performer, Vic Damone is finally calling it quits. Hence, ''A Farewell to Remember'' tour that comes to the Westbury Music Fair on Saturday. With more than 2,000 songs recorded, Mr. Damone, a Brooklyn native, has plenty of ''and then I sang'' hits to chose from when he bids his nostalgic goodbye at 8 p.m. at the theater, on Brush Hollow Road. (516) 334-0800.
Youth Sports Problems

Partnerships for Survival, a Smithtown group that provides support and information for adult survivors of child sexual abuse, screens ''Little Man'' today at 11 a.m. at the Cinema Arts Center on Park Avenue in Huntington. Featuring Frankie Muniz, the star of television's ''Malcolm in the Middle,'' the short film has won awards at such events as the International Sports Film Festival 2000 and Worldfest 2000. It will be followed by a panel discussion with speakers like the film's director, Howard Libov, and Marjorie Snyder, associate executive director of the Women Sports Foundation in East Meadow. (631) 265-7202.
Under the Big Top

If it's May (and/or early June), the circus is coming to town. Specifically, the Big Apple Circus is coming to the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University. This year's edition, ''Bello & Friends,'' pulls into Brookville on Friday to begin a 14-performance run through June 4. In addition to Bello Nock, a seventh-generation circus performer who won the Silver Clown Award at the 1998 International Circus Festival in Monte Carlo, the cast includes Francesco, a clown from France; Kirillas Verona and His Flying Trapese Troupe; the Jokers, from Russia; and Hernan Amestica, the Argentine hand-balancer who won the Gold Medal at the 1998 World Festival of the Circus of Tomorrow. (516) 299-3100.
Car Crazy

If a car is not just a means of transportation to you, two major car shows this week should be just what you need. Today, from noon to 5 p.m., the Chelsea Center, off Northern Boulevard in East Norwich, offers the ''Concours d'Elegance Jaguar Show,'' giving members of the Long Island Jaguar Club the chance to show off their vehicles from the 1920's to 2000. (516) 571-8550.

The American Cancer Society gains from a doubleheader over the weekend: From 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Saturday, the Hamptons Auto Classic Auction feature such items as a 1926 Rolls Royce Phantom I Piccadilly Roadster, the oldest in existence with its original body, and a 1931 Pierce Arrow Model Rumble Seat Roadster. Then, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. next Sunday, the ''Hamptons Concours d'Elegance,'' with about 70 privately owned classic cars, including a 1910 Isotta Fraschini and a 1927 Bugatti Model 35, will be on exhibit. Both events are at Sayre Park on Snake Hollow Road in Brideghampton. (631) 287-6277.
Going to the Dogs

More than 1,500 dogs representing 135 breeds will strut their stuff from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. today and tomorrow in the Long Island Kennel Club's 98th Annual All-Breed Dog Shows and Obedience Trials on the grounds of the Nassau County Museum of Art, off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor. Judging of individual breeds starts at 9 a.m. today and continues until late afternoon with the selection of Best in Show, and special demonstrations will be mounted throughout the day. A second show is set for tomorrow morning. (516) 676-9506.
Bay Street Bows

The Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor opens its season Wednesday with a hit import from London's West End, ''The Woman in Black -- A Ghost Play.'' Adapted by Stephen Mallatratt from the book by Susan Hill, the thriller stars the veteran stage and film actor Josef Sommer as a London solicitor who hires a professional actor, Jason Butler Harner, to help him re-enact and thereby exorcise the terrifying experiences of his youth. Directed by Leonard Foglia, the ''spine chiller'' runs through June 11 and will be followed by ''Hedda Gabler,'' June 21 through July 9; ''Love, Janis: The Songs, the Letters, the Soul of Janis Joplin,'' July 19 through Aug. 6, and ''You Can't Take It With You,'' Aug. 16 through Sept. 3 (631) 725-9500.
Free Choices

TODAY -- Checkers anyone? Champions in the board game that just won't go away will be crowned in the Five Towns Checker Championship at North Woodmere Park. The action begins at 11 a.m. with contenders divided into two groups: 13- to 19-year-olds and, wishfully thinking, ''20- to 120-year-olds.'' Registration is at 10 a.m. (516) 791-7777.

WEDNESDAY -- The Senior Pops Orchestra, under Joseph Manso's baton, plays lights classics, Broadway show tunes and other pop music at 1 p.m. in Roosevelt Hall on the Farmingdale campus of the State University. (631) 751-5425.
FRIDAY -- The Long Island Composers Alliance devotes its concert at 8 p.m. at the Cultural Center Theater on Hofstra University's Hempstead campus to ''Music by and for Students.'' (516) 799-8815.
